awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Privacy Attacks and Defense Mechanisms in Online Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
In online social networks, people and their connections often share personal information, such as demographics, interests, and opinions, and leave traces of their interaction with others and content in the network. Not everyone wants to share personal information; however, people's attributes are correlated with each other among themselves, with attributes of nearby people in the network, and between a person's accounts on different networks. These correlations create risks around inferring attributes people would rather keep private.  This project will try to identify and quantify the risks by developing new ways to infer attributes by leveraging these correlations, then develop defense mechanisms in two common social networking tasks.  For querying social network datasets, which is commonly used in advertising and research, the researchers will develop new differential privacy techniques for networks to ensure that query results do not inadvertently identify individual users or their attributes.  For matching social network profiles, which is often used in recommender systems, the team will develop novel similarity matching methods that work on encrypted personal data.  Overall, the research will provide a deeper understanding of the risks of inadvertent leakage of personal information and possible technical and policy approaches for addressing those risks. The project will also provide research opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students at three institutions, and the research team will emphasize recruiting students from historically underrepresented groups in computing both at the college and high school level. 

The project is organized around three main thrusts. The first thrust is to develop inference attacks on users' attributes and identity in social networks. To do this the team will first compute the relative discriminatory power of different attributes based on their distributions in the network, then use this and network structural information to perform attribute inference through affinity propagation. The second thrust focuses on improving differential privacy protection for graph queries. For this, the team will define similarity metrics that account for the non-independence of edges in social networks to better protect attribute privacy and develop new query techniques based on subgraph partitioning and consideration of the sensitivity of the query function. They will also develop new variants of differential privacy based on k-anonymity that hide a user's attributes relative to those of similar users. The third thrust explores how to do profile matching without revealing sensitive personal information, inspired by ideas from secure multiparty computation.  Here, the team will develop efficient and accurate methods to do dot-product computation on data protected by chaos-based encryption and keyword search on data protected by attribute-set-based encryption, as well as hashing-based approaches to compute image similarity without sharing the image data itself.  The team will release its code, suitably protected datasets, and tutorials and educational materials through a dedicated project website, and do outreach to members of underrepresented groups through the McNair programs, Women in Computer Science, the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers, and the National Society of Black Engineers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Online Social Network (OSN) data contain valuable insight into social behaviors and reveal the underlying benefits. Machine learning, data mining, and big data technologies have been utilized recently to discover meaningful social information from market analysis to counterterrorism. On the other hand, OSN data can also be taken advantage of by adversaries to launch inference attacks to figure out users? sensitive information that is unwillingly published by users. Privacy leakage has already resulted in serious damage to both individuals and societies. Inference attacks usually employ statistical analysis, machine learning, or data mining techniques to infer sensitive information. Thus, the ultimate goals of this project are to understand inference attacks and develop novel privacy preservation mechanisms for social network data.

In this project, we have tackled a few critical challenges for privacy-preserving social networking. Firstly, we devote our effort to inference attacks and develop novel solutions to overcome the challenges of data correlation among social networks. Next, we introduce several novel differential privacy notions and address the unique challenges resulting from the dependences inherent to social networks. After that, we investigate the challenges placed by statistical analysis attacks suffered by fine-grained profile matching, the high computation overhead of the existing searchable encryption-based approaches, and profile matching with images as attributes. Finally, all the aforementioned models and methods are evaluated extensively, through both theoretical analysis and experimental performance tests on large real-world datasets.

The project provides valuable resources for privacy attacks and defense mechanisms in online social networks. Many results have been published in top-notched journals and conferences, including IEEE Communications Magazine, IEEE Network, IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering, IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, etc.

The outcomes of this research broadly impact the nation?s emerging social network applications, especially given the increasing public concerns over private data collected from social media. The technical impacts of this project are fundamental as well as practical. The outcomes initiate a new research direction in online social network privacy protection. Several new methodologies, algorithms, and tools have emerged from this project and will benefit the society in general. The theoretical framework proposed in this project can be used as guidelines for privacy protection in social networks. The project outcomes also result in several critical strategies useful for many popular social network applications which suffer from the challenge of privacy leakage. The project results have been also published at  several prestigious conferences where PIs and their students have given presentations to publicize the research outcomes.

This project also develops accessible, meaningful, and affordable learning materials for students at both undergraduate and graduate levels from GSU, GMU, and GWU. The project outcomes have been adopted as course materials in many courses, such as Internet of Things, Machine Learning, Privacy, and Privacy Aware Computing, which heighten students? awareness and understanding of privacy issues in social networks. The state-of-the-art technologies in privacy protection inspire many students to do research in these areas. It is worth mentioning that some PhD students partially supported by this project have finished their dissertations and have become tenure-track professors right after graduation.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2022
Modified by: Zhipeng Cai
